review_title: Experience and benefits are good, but...

cons: you'll have to jump out eventually, the salary is not that competitive, you'll be forced to have multiple experience in non-related fields if you're floating and waiting for project calls (this happened to me two months but the first 3rd week I am already being offered to retool already). If given the opportunity, the management will force you to retool and drop what you really want to do.

pros: I like that as Beauty Advisors we are never taught to push products simply to achieve a sale. They train us on how to sell and teach us about the company and it’s values which are amazing and have us try to reflect this in our sales strategies. Most retail positions in multinational companies barely have any benefits for part timers. However I found out that there are some incentives in place for working Part Time. We get some coverage and health insurance it’s doesn’t cover everything but it does help out if needed which is still better than other companies. We have paid training and all of our concerns are fairly evaluated and taken into consideration. The small team also helps me feel more connected to my fellow coworkers. The company also has certain apps or lessons in place that help us maintain and live a healthier lifestyle and some other small incentives here and there. I’ve never had an issue with scheduling and my manager is always really understanding about my scheduling restrictions. Being treated fairly and like an actual human really helps boost our productivity as well.
cons: Random promotional changes, average retail break time

Remuneration can take a hit if you are back from onsite.

review_title: Projects are great, Immigration & People Services are BAD
pros: The projects are great, and if you are paired with the right leader, your learning curve is amazing.
cons:
You'd think that an organization with more than 700k employees all over the world would have streamlined processes when it came to helping with immigration and relocation. But this company's immigration, mobility and people services are horrible and make it difficult for an employee. It makes one feel like they aren't valued for the tireless hours they put in. 

There is absolutely no support in people services, and every step in the way has been incrementally difficult and emotionally exhausting. 

But what's the point of great work when for international folks this place has caused so much distress?

review_title: Good Company but loosing Strategy Consulting Ambitions
pros:
- I actually got super cool c-level projects like IT strategy development, transformation roadmap planning, etc. >> cant complain here
- working hours reasonable, not like tier-1,tier-2
- good open culture, no internal feeling of competition
cons:
Accenture Strategy lost its ambitions: 
1. salary is not competing anymore with strategy consulting firms, falling way behind competitors like BCG Platinion
2. Leadership focus rather towards large scale transformations than smaller strategy engagements
- Too much unnecessary internal stuff like community calls, newsletters, etc., not focusing on what actually adds value
- laptop is ridiculous slow; feeling ashamed in front of the client sometimes
- Female talent & diversity is a top priority and targets (hiring, promotion) are pushed despite diluting brand value and loosing male talent

job_title: Program and Project Management Senior Analyst in Manila, Manila
pros:
Lots of opportunity for growth
Salary is competitive
Plenty of trainings
cons:
The culture is dependent on your department or project.
You can be transferred without much choice, and be offered hybrid positions, which is management’s way of adding more work into your plate without additional cost. This can easily put too much on your plate since no one manager is looking out for you, it can split your priorities, and can lead to lack of visibility, and burn out.
Also, they value tenure when it comes to rewards and recognition. As a top performer of high achiever, this is not a good environment for you. And though there are many trainings, the sheer amount of deliverables keeps you from maximizing these learning opportunities.

pros:
Some half-decent benefits e.g. very comprehensive health insurance (only due to the nature of the content viewed - others don't have as much cover) and occasional gift cards/treats (which could be replaced by better salaries but whatever).

In theory, a nice diverse crowd of people to work with.
cons:
Management sucks - corporate America BS through and through. They'll lie through their teeth and bend over backwards to those who hang out with them in smoking areas or whoever kisses up the most, especially when it comes to promotions and changing roles. If you're neither of these, you're stuffed.

Accenture seriously believes ''wellness coaches'' is them doing their bit to help those who may suffer from possible trauma from the content being seen when all these ''coaches'' do is give breathing techniques. Staff need psychiatrists, not that.

Staff are all nice and friendly at first but you soon realise no one is really worthy of any sort of friendship in or out of the office.

job_title: Subject Matter Expert (SME) in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
Company transport
Fair package
Growth opportunities if you work like a machine and please your seniors.
cons:
Where do I start from:
Time consuming hiring process: takes 4-5 months
No new learning: you stick to what you're hired for and keep doing that for 10 hrs a day 5 days a week.
Leaves: though Accenture gives around 35 leaves a year (including planned leaves, public holidays, sick leaves) but the management won't let you take leaves. You always have to fight for it 
No perks: other than your salary don't expect anything. Literally "anything". Forget Diwali, Christmas gift . In 3 year they once just gave a box that had samosa and banana on Diwali.
Work life balance: There's no work life balance. If you try to give your best to work then your personal life will get affected. If you try to pay attention to personal life then your work life will get affected.

review_title: Can be majorly different depending on what division/department you're in
pros: Decent work life balance. Lots of Clients. Depending on what department you end up in and what client you are working for it could be great or terrible. I had a great job and management team in one department, but things change with the wind. The next department was a nightmare. You seem to have decent job security in the sense that when a department contract ends you don't lose your job, but there doesn't seem to be much transparency on where you go. There might not be a job that fits your skillset, so you just get plugged in somewhere that's an entire misfit. Overall, it seems the company is so large it's like a lot of smaller companies put together, so I can only speak the small piece of the company I've experienced. Benefits are overall good. Lots of training. Didn't get the feeling of overall high turnover. Lots of other companies recognize Accenture and will take interest in hiring you while working here. A lot of skills to be gained.
cons: Pay lags behind the market rate. Too many meetings. Majorly disconnected management with too many layers. Over segmentation. Top-down communication and lack of value placed on employee feedback. Orders get given from someone you've never spoken to with no sense of reason. Needs to be more focus on collaboration as a team to actually accomplish the goal. Lots of unclear directions. There are way too many systems and there's always at least one not working correctly. Too many IT teams that don't seem to take responsibility to communicate with each other and get an issue solved. Trying to find to right person responsible for something can be a hunt that lasts forever. They need to simplify their internal processes and understand employees don't have all day to decipher long complicated emails with no clear purpose. Too many revolving managers who are clueless as to what is going on. Lots of hands in the pot and layers of disconnected management. Too many internal requirements that add little to no real value.

No compulsion on coming to office - even before covid Accenture had adopted WFH model.
cons:
Monotonous work - I did 4-5 project, for 2-3 clients, all very similar. No learning and growth after certain time. They don't entertain your request to change teams too.
Long Hours - As in all service/ consultant companies, you have to under short deadlines which is very stressful.

pros:
- Market-leading level of most / all talent sets imaginable -- mostly brought about by aggressive acquisition strategies, particularly in the digital space
- Some extremely caring and extremely intelligent leaders who have made peace with how to be successful despite the many obstacles and ongoing bureaucracy of org size 
- The new Droga-led direction of Interactive is encouraging but too early to gauge
cons:
- Darwinian experiment-like survival is an accepted part of company; this aspect is placed above and trumps any efforts at achieving a coherent company culture; this persisting ready/fire/aim, and "acquire now/integrate never" dynamic places the bulk of the pressure on managers and senior managers still aspiring to achieve the coveted Managing Director promotion; and once achieved, most discover the organizational goal posts have simply moved towards that of Senior MD; the money is "just enough" to stay for roughly half
- By any reasonable measure, and regardless of political leanings, new CEO and leadership has bizarrely over-indexed on woke stances and policy implementations to the detriment of client value, market impact, and shareholder value
- Significant % of senior-level leadership actively avoids doing work, instead favoring internal political gameplay (look busy, be unreachable, attach yourself to successful teams) instead of contributing tangible productive impact and influence over those efforts

review_title: What does the Firm mean to me?
job_title: Agile Coach in New York, NY
pros:
I have worked with Accenture in two countries - the US and India. I felt that there is deep respect for one another and one can trust & rely upon another to deliver on commitments.

There was an extremely high degree of ownership and accountability at an individual level - a deep sense of personal commitment.

I salute the commitment to "Performance Achievement" at a scale that is daunting - it takes tremendous courage on the part of leadership to initiate this and support it, knowing fully well that it takes multiple years to achieve the intended outcome.
cons: Accenture's greatest strength can also be its weakness. Its size and speed can cause scary moments - particularly when multiple countries & cultures are involved. The change can be daunting and structures are needed to navigate the rough waters.

review_title: What they made a pregnant student go through:
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lisbon, Lisbon District
pros: - Some benefits were nice
cons:
Horrifying company to be a pregnant woman, and full time student. I'm not quite sure where to start but:

- Forced me to go into the office during the pandemic while pregnant, months after having had a miscarriage. People with asthma were allowed to stay home, but not me.

- Categorically refused to give me vacation days when I had to study for my finals and was in the first few months of my pregnancy. A few days later I was diagnosed with hydramniosis, acute anemia, and birth defects were found in my baby. I called them several times sobbing and even begged for temporary unpaid leave, was told it would take up to a month to approve. Keep in mind I worked until 1 am and had to get up for class at 7. They didn't care.

- Since I was so utterly exhausted, I of course flunked the aforementioned finals and lost my scholarship at the university

- My baby died two days after giving birth. When I came back to the office and requested a change of department so I wouldn't have to view graphic content, I never heard back from them. I was encouraged to view training material which included dead babies stuffed in a toilet and fetuses strewn across the floor.

- Eventually psychologically wore me down until I quit showing up for work and eventually quit. I'm awaiting their response but I'm sure I will be financially penalized for not giving the obligatory 30 day notice.

review_title: Extremely low employee-centricity; No Leadership vision
pros:
1. Streamlined  internal processes
2. Flexible timings
3. Good Pay for laterals
cons:
1. Appraisals are dependent on current trends, your relationship with your supervisor and their capacity to fight for you. You could be stuck in the same role for a long time with no justification if your manager can't fight for you. 

Also, you could be sidelined for women and LGBTQ candidates with the justification that the organisation wants to promote diversity and so a specific class of candidates will be promoted irrespective of their contribution to the Accenture and client business.

2. Work culture has degraded lately. Politics can be felt till the most junior levels.

3. Primary focus is on extracurriculars rather than delivering business value for clients. Appraisals are also judged on how well you support the extracurricular activities like Diversity, Inclusion, etc.

4. Lack of strategy and focus from leadership.

5. Too much effort and time spent on advertising the latest industry buzzwords than actually building business cases and credibility in delivering solutions.

6. The organisation is known to fire employees in bulk like they did during the COVID-19 pandemic and then hire laterals immediately.

pros: Lot of career growth opportunities
cons: if you don’t have big 4 experience can be tricky to navigate. Very large firm

review_title: Going to Accenture is like a full stop to your growth.
job_title: Data Science Analyst in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: You can get by here without working or get miserably if you really like to work
cons:
Leadership
- Most of the people in the leadership are organically grown and see any lateral hire as an outsider
- If you are a lateral joiner, there is a high probability that the during the interview process the MD of your division (AI in my case) has mislead you about the kind of work Accenture does (they'll paint a very rosy picture and answer all and any of your questions in an affirmative which is far from reality)

Salary and compensation
- Don't ever think about going to Accenture if you are hailing from a better organization, they'll put a full stop to your growth
- The hiring HR would promise expectations but at the time of delivery they'll back out and mocking you that why didn't you get it in writing. Personal experience: promised me an variable of 20%+ but got less than 8% reason given that I already have a high CTC (they shouldn't have hired me if they thought CTC was high). Promised me that I'll be eligible for the increment cycle but introduced a new policy barring any new joiner to a part of first increment cycle

Quality or work 
- You won't get any kind of work satisfaction here
- The management will choose the easy approach instead of the right approach. Be it client or employee
- Questionable work ethics

Concen raising
- Here your concern would only be heard upon but no action will ever be taken to resolve that

IT equipment
- The company is even being frugal in giving the IT equipments and expect the employees to deliver quick with previous generation laptops
